title: ‘Mozart’ Review: The Composer as Novelist
sub_head: Mozart may be famed as a prodigy, but Jan Swafford celebrates his apprehension of humanity in full.
body:
One January night in 1761, little Wolfgang Mozart insisted on playing a challenging harpsichord piece he had just heard performed by his older sister, already a virtuoso. He had never played a keyboard before. At the beginning of “Mozart: The Reign of Love” (don’t let the sappy subtitle put you off), the esteemed composer and biographer Jan Swafford writes:


Three years later, on his first visit to London, the prodigy, it was reported, was rolling around on a table when someone handed him a song by Johann Christian Bach. “The boy glanced at the score upside down, pointed out a wrongly copied note, and continued his roll on the table.”
Mr. Swafford delights in repeating these stories—it’s one of the pleasures of this comprehensive and engaging biography. He is thoroughly up-to-date on the latest information and controversies, debunking the still commonly held mythology about the composer, and he continually reminds us of what astounding music Mozart wrote: “No artist,” Mr. Swafford asserts, “made more of pleasure—made it deeper, more liberated, more sensual.”
